I have some Bronze Age jewellery - glass and amber beads - and they have been drilled to take a thong. That drilling was done with a sliver of bone or deer antler. Through glass. They must have had tremendous patience, and all the time in the world.
The beads are real - I had them examined at the local museum. They were found in a field, where several Tumuli (burial mounds) had been ploughed out, centuries before. The land owner wasn't interested, which is how I came to have them.

"I was using a stick in a drill." Um... no, you weren't. You were using an industrial abrasive. The stick was just acting like a crappier version of sandpaper or a grinding disc for the abrasive to stick to and move against the rock. The drill was just moving the stick.

So... can an industrial gemstone abrasive cut rock? Of course it can. Duh. It could also cut steel, titanium, molybdenum, or basically anything with a lower hardness scale.

Get a stick of a hard hardwood stick, fairly straight and use something to basically hollow it out. Find some harder rock and use rocks to bash together to make a sand from the smashed stones(that will create a harder abrasive that was fractured apart for a more aggressive grit). Take some clay and put it around the hole's location to create a dam. Dribble some sand and water slurry through the center and rotate stick slowly and with a steady downward force. a few hours or days later and Grogg has hole.

Dry abrasive has less friction than wet abrasive, plus wet abrasive stays put better than dry. Hemp string and sand can cut through rock, as long as it's wet! Should work for the wooden drill bits as well.
